instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.

threads.title: (Solved) Dead SMC? MBA <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No light, no fan, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Hi all.
I have a Macbook Air that suffered water damage.
Very minimal amount, from the look of it.

Cleaned.
No Magsafe light, no fan.

Checked voltages and missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.

<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> 20.5v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 20.5v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.2v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42v
F7140 is 8.2v each side
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> Looks OK

I'm suspecting the SMC, from reading a few other posts, but any suggestions appreciated.
Thanks.

threads.title: (Solved) Dead SMC? MBA <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No light, no fan, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Where was the area liquid got on? Do you have other S5 rails present? Check the diode reading on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. Also if you have  <SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>. Are <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS present? <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> present?

If you have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> present then you should have green light on charger, unless J9500 or I/O cable are corroded.  Inspect them, also take a look at IPD flex connector (trackpad flex), area around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.

If water affected SMC area reflow it.

threads.title: (Solved) Dead SMC? MBA <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No light, no fan, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
SMC must be reballed, if has sign of corrosion close to its area.

Post voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.
If get <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> should be present too.
Check if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS are present.
If yes, check also <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: (Solved) Dead SMC? MBA <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No light, no fan, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Hi Narek.
Thanks for the prompt reply.
<SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> are both 0 volts.


[B][I]Where was the area liquid got on? [/I][/B]
There was very little water on the board...however I cannot remember exactly where, as I cleaned the board several weeks ago, and then had to wait ages for the customer to get back to me as to whether to attempt to repair it.
I should have taken a photo of it - I will from now on.

From memory, it was mainly around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, near the wireless card, and also near the SD card reader- especially around <CHIP>U4400</CHIP>.

[B][I]Do you have other S5 rails present?[/I][/B]

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> : 1.23v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> : 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> : 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_DBGLED</SIGNAL> : 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_R</SIGNAL> : 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> : 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5RS3RS0_SYSCLKGEN</SIGNAL> : 0v

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> : 8.17v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> : 8.17v

<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDD</SIGNAL> : 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL> : 5.1v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 0v

<SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> : 3.42v

[I][B]Diode reading[/B][/I]
with red on ground and black on L4820, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> reads 0.392.

[I][B]Do you have <SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>?[/B][/I]
No...
0v

[B][I]Are <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS present? [/I][/B]
No.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> : 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> : 0v
[I][B][/B][/I]
[B][I]<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> present? [/I][/B]

No.
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> : 0v

[B][I]If you have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> present then you should have green light on charger, unless J9500 or I/O cable are corroded. Inspect them, also take a look at IPD flex connector (trackpad flex), area around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>. [/I][/B]

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.42v
No green light

Tried with known good 821-1722-A cable that connects J9500 to the DC-in daughter board.
Tried with known good DC-in daughter board.
Tried with known good genuine Apple 85 Watt AC adaptor.
Also tried charger, DC-in daughter board and 821-1722-A cable in another MBA - it works fine, green light, fan comes on, etc
So charger, daughter board, and 821-1722-A cable are definitely working

I've inspected J9500 under a microscope, and it looks perfect.
The IPD flex connector also looks immaculate.

The area around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> looks fine, as well, with nothing obvious standing out.

threads.title: (Solved) Dead SMC? MBA <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No light, no fan, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Reball SMC first.
It looks dead, maybe <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> doesn't even arrive to its ball.

threads.title: (Solved) Dead SMC? MBA <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No light, no fan, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Thanks 2informaticos.
Sorry, I posted the above to Narek before realising you had also posted.

I just checked <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>, and I get 3.1v.

I'll try to reball the SMC. 
Thank you.

threads.title: (Solved) Dead SMC? MBA <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No light, no fan, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
I already saw that signal.
The thing is that SMC may not receive it, if corresponding ball is corroded.

You also need to check voltage and signals for <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> (2 OF 2) at page 37.

threads.title: (Solved) Dead SMC? MBA <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No light, no fan, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Sorry for the lack of update.

I tried to reflow the SMC chip without reballing it, and surprisingly, the unit now works!
Surprising, as there was no evidence of any liquid having been near it.
Thank you both Narek and 2informaticos, I appreciate you help and advice.
